comments.body: I can do that, but it will be harder to understand the comment afterwards which is referring only to the second part of the if.
I think it's same, there's still hyperv check and the comments are also there
In the case of `CONTAINER_NETWORK` set, containers are running with docker network, which means the IP should be get from docker inspect.
To use with CNI plugins, CONTAINER_NETWORK should be unset. Do you have any problem if keeping CONTAINER_NETWORK not set?

In case ``CONTAINER_NETWORK`` is unset, it will use the mode for version 1709 which is unsupported on Windows Server RTM. It will try to pass to the containers from the same pod ``--net=container:<Pod Infra Container Id>`` (more details in this commit https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/commit/d7f9e22815aede0b1ab77e0b8f87331e4f214e2a).
Having ``CONTAINER_NETWORK`` set will make kubelet connect the container to the network set in that environment variable. Then it will call the CNI which will be able to perform some additional operations before returning the IP.
Again, the environment variable is the one deciding if it should use the mode for Windows Server 1709 or Windows Server RTM. Not setting the environment variable will assume the version is Windows Server 1709 and will result in doing unsupported operations.

This change affects only kubelet which runs on Windows Server RTM (build number 14393) and will not affect the newer Windows Server versions (build number 16299 or higher).
For Hyper-V container, no need to call modifyHostNetworkOptionForContainer.
Does this mean that hyperV isolated containers will not have any networking by default?
no, hyperV container's network will be set by CNI plugins
Please add a comment explaining what you're returning here and why. I assume this is not the "namesapce"
should we add some warning logs for unsupported features on windows?
Added log when user has set seccomp annotations.
